title: How to Make Pork Gravy

steps.headline: Know that pork gravy is made from the drippings of cooked pork.
steps.description: In order to collect the drippings to make the gravy, you need to cook the pork first. This can be done in one of two ways. Roast the pork: Select your cut of pork and place it in a oven-proof dish or pan fat-side down. Preheat the oven to 400°F (204°C). When the oven has heated, place the roasting dish and pork into the oven. Roast the pork for 30 minutes and then flip it so the pork is fat-side up. Rotating the pork allows the whole pork cut to roast thoroughly. Remove the pork and let it stand for 10 minutes. Sautee pork chops: Season your pork chops with salt and pepper on both sides. Heat butter in a large skillet or pan on medium-high heat. If you prefer, you can use olive oil instead of butter. Place the pork chops in the skillet and cook them until they are brown on both sides and cooked all the way through. This should take three to five minutes. The pork is done when the meat is white on the inside.

steps.headline: Collect the juices from the cooked pork.
steps.description: When you pick the meat up from the pan or skillet, hold the meat over the pan for a few second. Doing this allows the extra juices to drip off the meat and into the pan.

steps.headline: Pour the juices from the pan or skillet into a glass measure.
steps.description: The glass measure allows you to see when the fat separates from the juices. Let the drippings stand in the container until the fat floats to the top. If you do not have a glass measure, you can use a small cooking pot.

steps.headline: Skim the fat from the top once it has separated from the juices.
steps.description: Put the fat in its own small stove top pan. You will need roughly three tablespoons of the fat for the gravy.

steps.headline: Put the fat back on the stove.
steps.description: You should have three tablespoons of fat. Place the pan with the fat back on the stove. Add three tablespoons of flour to the fat and stir.

steps.headline: Cook the flour and fat over medium heat.
steps.description: You should cook the mixture for one to two minutes, stirring constantly. Make sure to scrape any browned bits free from the bottom and sides of the pan.

steps.headline: Add ingredients to your drippings.
steps.description: You will want to have 2 cups of dripping mixture. Measure how much drippings you have and then pour the drippings into a mixing bowl. Add the liquids of your choice so that you have two cups of drippings. Add pork broth or stock to your drippings for a truly salty, pork flavor. Add sherry or red for a more gourmet gravy. Gravies benefit from a bit of acidity. Wines or sherries add a depth of flavor to the gravy that comes from the addition of the acidity. Some people enjoy making gravy by mixing the drippings with a can of cream of mushroom soup.

steps.headline: Add the drippings mixture to the flour and fat mixture.
steps.description: Stir both mixtures in the pan over medium heat. The gravy should become smooth and thick. Add salt and pepper to taste. If it is not thick enough for your taste, add another tablespoon of flour.

steps.headline: Pour your gravy over your pork and any other side dishes you may have cooked.

tyn: Pork drippings and the pan the pork was cooked in
Flavorful liquid (chicken stock, pork broth, vegetable stock, potato water, wine, cream of mushroom soup)
